NAMA's understanding was that they could not use any information, which seems to be different to Cerberus's understanding.

Not at all Deputy. What I specifically asked Brown Rudnick prior to our engagement was in connection with the information and the material it was going to give us and whether there were any restrictions - legal, contractual or otherwise - on the use of the information and on the provision of the information to us. My question was not limited solely to PIMCO. It was limited to how it got the information from anywhere. My direct understanding was it had the contractual right to share that information with us. To the extent there is information in the data room, and we have never done an analysis to see whether it overlapped, I had the information anyway. We had access to the data.
What Mr. Neporent is saying is solely in reference to the data room regarding whatever information Brown Rudnick had when it was engaging with PIMCO.

No Deputy, I did not say just the data room, but it would be subsumed in my statement. We asked it specifically whether there were any restrictions, be it related to the data room, the NAMA non-disclosure agreement, PIMCO or any other relationship it had in connection with the development of the information. It was a very broadly-stated representation.
We will come back to it with Mr. McDonagh and NAMA when they return.

I welcome Mr. Neporent and thank him for his submissions to date and for his statement. I do not doubt his credentials or those of Cerberus in general but there is one line in the statement at paragraph 4.1 to the effect that Cerberus is committed to high ethical standards in the conduct of its business and that this commitment is and always has been a paramount component of its culture and tone at the top. I do not like the tone of this comment. It very much goes to the crux of the issue with regard to Mr. Neporent and his firm. It smacks a little of elitism and a culture that exists. Before Mr. Neporent arrived, we spoke about the auspicious name of the firm, Cerberus, which is the three-headed dog that guards the gates of hell. It is quite interesting because it seems to be guarding a culture of opportunism and, in my view, there was opportunism at play. Mr. Neporent stated that there was an unsolicited approach from Brown Rudnick to the firm but, nonetheless, questions arise in respect of the process in itself.

At the bottom of paragraph 3.3, Mr. Neporent states that at no time prior or subsequent to Cerberus's involvement with Project Eagle did it work directly or indirectly with PIMCO or any other actual or prospective bidder involved in the process relating to project. He also states, at paragraph 3.13, that Brown Rudnick provided Cerberus with due diligence material, a point he confirmed earlier to Deputy Cullinane and two other Deputies. These statements do not tally because there is an indirect link. A moment ago, Mr. Neporent stated Brown Rudnick had a contractual right to share information with Cerberus. This is of concern because in the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General there were many complaints by other bidders who stated they did not receive enough information on the portfolio assets or enough time. I am of the view that Cerberus was given an unfair advantage because of the salient and vital information it had on making the bid. It was also the only bidder over the reserve price. It is also very interesting that it had no investment history - Mr. Neporent stated this himself - in Northern Ireland heretofore. Then it engaged this firm which approached it and an opportunity was taken. Cerberus took an opportunity. The risk was taken only on the basis that it would secure the bid. This is the underlying theme. The comment made, almost as an obiter dictumor off-the-cuff remark, about tone at the top indicates this to me.

What is also interesting is that NAMA described the assets as low value but Cerberus was still interested in bidding. I know I have spoken a little bit, but I would like Mr. Neporent to answer some of this for me, if he does not mind.
I am not sure if there is a question in there-----
There is a question-----
-----but if the Deputy could articulate the question, I will be happy to answer it.
-----and the question relates to whether the means justify the end. There is a question regarding Cerberus's handling of this and in respect of it availing of an opportunity.

If the Deputy articulates that question I will be happy to answer it. Of course there was an opportunity. The opportunity was generated by NAMA. NAMA put the portfolio up for sale. As one of the six, eight or ten largest buyers of portfolios such as this in the world, we saw it as an opportunity, if the Deputy wants me to use her word-----
Does Mr. Neporent accept-----
-----but we did not create the opportunity. We participated in a public process - in a public auction - and were the winning bidder.

Does Mr. Neporent accept that when all of the component parts of this story are put together, the sum of them becomes a whole that is a little indirect. The two paragraphs I quoted demonstrate that for me. Does Mr. Neporent accept that there was an indirect link to PIMCO, notwithstanding what he said in his opening statement?

I put those paragraphs in the letter in response to other testimony I had heard before the committee in order to lay to rest the rumour or innuendo that Cerberus was a surrogate for PIMCO and that in any way were they involved with us in the bid. If the Deputy feels I have chosen my words inartfully, for this I apologise, but that is what I intended to convey-----
I understand that-----
-----to directly answer the questions raised in this room.

I accept what Mr. Neporent is saying on PIMCO itself. However, I am referring to Brown Rudnick and its previous relationship. PIMCO withdrew from the process but Brown Rudnick had been working with it on 12 March and then Cerberus engaged Brown Rudnick on March 24.
Yes.
Mr. Neporent has already said it shared the information with Cerberus. Does he believe other bidders were disadvantaged by the fact Cerberus had this information?
I do not believe so. A lot of the information was historic. I believe some of it related to valuations.
How was it historic when there was such a short period between 12 March and 24 March? How could it possibly be historic?

Much of the information related to numbers they had probably around the year 2009. The information in the data room was more current. This is what I mean. Some of the information was historic and some of the information-----
I find that difficult to believe. If, however, that is Mr. Neporent's opinion, of course he is entitled to it. Does he think that in any way the other bidders were at a disadvantage?

I do not know what information the other bidders had. I do not know what kind of effort they put into the process. I can only tell the Deputy from our perspective we felt there was real competitive tension here. We were nervous that we were not going to win the bid and we were doing what we could, within the guidelines and rules set out by NAMA, to win the bid.
Does Mr. Neporent accept the fact that Cerberus only made a bid because it knew it was going to get it?
I do not accept that at all Deputy.

It is obvious that Cerberus is quite careful with money, particularly in light of the £2.8 million in dispute, which the Comptroller and Auditor General has identified as approximately 20% of the £15 million paid to Brown Rudnick when Cerberus already had other advisers. That is evident and I presume Mr. Neporent would accept this. It is almost a rhetorical question. I will move to the question I want to ask.

Cerberus knew the reserve price was £1.3 billion. It would have been in the interests of Cerberus to know if there were other bidders and how many there were. Would Cerberus try to find out such things while it was in a bidding process?

Sure. One would like to know what the competition was and what they were doing. Often, though, that information is not available and can only be speculated on. In a transaction of this size there are only a handful of logical bidders, of which PIMCO is not really one. PIMCO is not really recognised as a player in this market, something which was recognised in the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General. It has only a small percentage of the market and there are only a handful of players that one would expect to see.

Cerberus knew that PIMCO had exited the process and it would have known that PIMCO had experts available to it, of which one was Brown Rudnick. In his opening statement, Mr. Neporent mentioned Brown Rudnick offering its services to another bidder so Brown Rudnick obviously knew there was another bidder to whom it could go if Cerberus did not take its services. Would this have been a piece of intelligence as to who else was in play?

We knew there were other bidders because Lazard was telling us, quite forcefully, that other bidders were looking at the portfolio. We assumed until the day of the award that we were not the only bidder in the process but we had no idea who was in.
If it knew there was another bidder to whom it could offer its services it could presumably name that bidder. Did it do that?
No. The Deputy would have to ask it what it knew. I did not follow up on that question as it did not seem important at the time.

Brown Rudnick would have had sight of the data room. I accept that there was a non-disclosure agreement but it is very difficult to forget what one has seen. The detail from the data room cannot be disclosed but it would be useful to know what direction to take to look at something and some things might not be precluded by a non-disclosure agreement. Cerberus was told that it could see a limited amount of information. Did it get the impression that more information was made available to PIMCO and others than to it after PIMCO had withdrawn?

I do not believe so. It was noted in the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General that there were thousands of documents in the data room and we looked at 100% of those documents through our team which had access to the room.
Was the time available adequate for this or too short?

Given a portfolio of this size the time period was condensed and we would have preferred more time. When one enters into a process such as this one has to commit time, resources and money. Maybe you will win and maybe you will not but we decided we had enough time to work with the data and put in a bid.
Cerberus is a very large firm and would have had to bring in a range of experts, which is a big commitment if there was the prospect of not winning.
That happens often, and more often than I would like.
Did Cerberus engage Brown Rudnick before or after the other experts?
In connection with Project Eagle?
Yes.
We engaged it after the others. We had legal, advisory and valuation teams in place almost immediately after being invited into the process.

Mr. Neporent answered Deputy MacSharry's question about the release from guarantees. He asked if all 55 were released and Mr. Neporent said that was not the case. Can he tell us what percentage were released from guarantee?

The unpaid principal balance in the original portfolio was approximately £4.4 billion. We have written off approximately £2.5 billion of that portfolio in connection with consensual resolutions of enforcement actions. Embedded in them are a number of guarantees but I do not know, off the top of my head, what the number might be. We can probably do some research and find that out if it is important to the committee.
Is it likely that these are assets based in Northern Ireland? Some were in other jurisdictions.
The majority of the assets were in Northern Ireland so I would guess that most of the debt forgiveness would also be in Northern Ireland.

The Minister for Finance told us he did not have any responsibility in this and it is stated in the Act that he is not permitted to get involved in the commercial aspect of NAMA's work. Why did Mr. Neporent direct the letter of investment to the Minister and not to NAMA?

We were trying to introduce ourselves to key stakeholders and this is typically what we do so that people understand how we would come in and what our investment philosophy was, to make sure that it coincided with what the preferred method of operation was. If it did not, we might take the decision not to bid.
Did the Minister advise Cerberus to go to NAMA or say it was not appropriate? Did he say he should not have received that information?

I believe that we were told, in the North and in the South, that price would be the determining factor and that, while social issues were important, NAMA would take the decision and price would be the primary driver of that decision.

A number of witnesses have said that the Northern Ireland portfolio was more difficult to deal with. Cerberus said it carried out research into the two jurisdictions and said it had not worked in or purchased assets in either of them previously. Was Mr. Neporent made aware of, or given to believe, there were different cultures in the two jurisdictions?

We have carried out our business in many countries with an UPB of over $80 billion since 2010 and 40 transactions with over 1 million borrowers. After a couple of years' experience, I do not think there is anything unique in the Northern Irish portfolio.
Can Mr. Neporent share information with us as to how the loans purchased by Cerberus performed afterwards?
There is still quite a bit to work out and that chapter in the book will be written some time in the future when the portfolio is resolved, all the assets sold and all the debt repaid.
Some of them have been sold already, though. What was the experience with those?

It has been positive. Over 700 assets have been refinanced or sold, of which approximately 400 are development assets. Our sense is that most of that was done on a consensual basis. I am not a macroeconomist and Cerberus does not make decisions based on macroeconomics but since our purchase, unemployment in the jurisdiction has gone down by 27%, from 7.7% to 5.6%, and housing prices are up by approximately 19%, suggesting it has gone rather well.
The witness is happy with the purchase.
Time, Deputy Murphy. I call Deputy Connolly.

We are not investigating Mr. Neporent. I thank him for attending the meeting. Our job is examine the Comptroller and Auditor General's report and the concerns he has raised regarding the sales process and a conflict of interest. From our point of view PIMCO was in place and was working on it for almost a year before it pulled out. Less than 12 days later it offered the witness its services.
That was Brown Rudnick.

Yes, Brown Rudnick. This has been raised in the Comptroller and Auditor General's report. I will ask some questions about that because I am not clear about what the witness's knowledge was about the withdrawal of PIMCO.
I will be happy to help as much as I can.
Okay. What was Mr. Neporent's knowledge of the withdrawal of PIMCO? What were the circumstances of its withdrawal?

As I said, we were approached by Mr. Keinan with this unsolicited idea. He told us that they had been working with PIMCO for about a year and that PIMCO had withdrawn. He did not tell us at that time that PIMCO had withdrawn the day before, only that it had withdrawn. We asked for the reasons. He said he did not really know but he thought potentially it was related to some issues in PIMCO with Bill Gross resigning or being under a cloud of controversy at PIMCO. He also mentioned to us that NAMA was unhappy that PIMCO had had an agreement with Mr. Cushnahan, a former NIAC member, to be compensated for services post-transaction. No mention was made of any services. We had no idea who Mr. Cushnahan was.
When he approached the witness on this day, whatever time it was after PIMCO withdrew, did the witness have a verbal chat with him?
Yes, I did.
Was it on the street or elsewhere?
No, on the telephone. His initial contact to one of my colleagues was on 14 March. This engagement was then raised with me, my staff and others.
It was not clarified to the witness that PIMCO's legal division rang NAMA and said it had concerns about a payment.
Nothing of the sort was shared with us.
Brown Rudnick did not share it with Cerberus.
No, it did not.
Did it share more information subsequently about the circumstances-----
No, it did not.
It never did.
No.
What exactly did the witness know about PIMCO's withdrawal?
I knew it withdrew. I only knew what Mr. Keinan told us, because we did not speak to PIMCO.
I am not sure what he told the witness about the withdrawal and about the issues in PIMCO.
I will try to be more clear. I think I am not doing an effective job. First, they told us that there was some controversy within PIMCO-----
Yes, I heard that.

-----with Mr. Gross and that it may have taken its eye off this ball and was going to focus on other things. Second, NAMA was unhappy with PIMCO because of PIMCO's disclosure of a potential prospective relationship with Mr. Cushnahan. That is it.
The witness did not know who he was.
I had no idea who he was.
Did the witness ask who he was?

Yes. They told us in that context that he was a former member of the advisory board, that it was intended that post-transaction Mr. Cushnahan would be an adviser to PIMCO in connection with the portfolio and that NAMA believed that was a conflict of interest and had the appearance of impropriety. That is what we were told.
Did Brown Rudnick tell the witness that it had been working with Mr. Cushnahan for quite some time?
They did not.
The witness did not ask any questions about that.
I did not see the need to.
With regard to the information Brown Rudnick gave Mr. Neporent, he had employed solicitors.
I am sorry, but employed what?
We have a clash of accents. My apologies. The witness had employed lawyers.
Yes.
The witness was happy with them.
Yes.
Does the witness think he would have been successful in his bid if he had just kept those solicitors or lawyers?
I really cannot speculate on that. It is hard to put me in that retrospective hypothetical situation.
At the time the witness clearly felt he was going to get something more by going with Brown Rudnick.
Absolutely.

The witness has been asked about the nature of that information. He is telling the committee that he asked them and they told him they had no difficulty giving him all of the information it had got from working with PIMCO right up to almost the bid.

The information they represented they had included information they had prior to their engagement with PIMCO. At least, that is what was represented to us. They had been working on this transaction perhaps since even before PIMCO. Their idea was that they would collect all of the information and then find somebody to be an exclusive buyer.
Was that even prior to April 2013?
That is my understanding.
Is the witness sure of that?

All I can tell the Deputy is what they told us. As I said, I have no understanding of when they started their work. We did not do an independent investigation of that. They simply told us this story in connection with seeking engagement by us.
Did they tell the witness about any documents they had to sign for NAMA - non-disclosure documents or the nature of the documents? Did they show them to the witness or did he ask for them?

I did not ask for them in that way. The way I managed that issue was that I asked them for specific representation that they had the legal and contractual ability to share with us all of the information they were going to share.
I find that difficult to understand. How could they have a contractual ability? The witness used the word "contractual" a few times. What does he mean by that?
Whether they were subject to any non-disclosure agreement anywhere else or subject to any confidential relationship or arrangement.
The witness asked them that question.
Yes.
What was their answer?
The answer was, "We are free to share this information with you in an unrestricted, unlimited way".
Then the witness employed them. When did he tell NAMA about his new advisers?
About Brown Rudnick specifically?
No, there were property advisers as well. Did the witness not take on somebody else too?
Yes, we took on New River Retail. We disclosed prior to getting New River Retail engaged because New River Retail needed access to the data room.
On page 80 of the Comptroller and Auditor General's report there is a chapter entitled "Undertakings on engagement of advisors".
Yes.

It states: "Potential bidders appoint professional advisors..." and goes on to outline the change. In 4.55 it states: "Prospective bidders [that is, the witness] for Project Eagle were required to seek written consent from NAMA in relation to any advisors they wished to engage or retain during the loan sale process."
Yes, I see that.
It goes on to say that Cerberus informed Lazard of its intention to engage New River Retail. Did the witness tell Lazard about Brown Rudnick?

No. As I said, we did not think we had to because Brown Rudnick was not getting access to the data room. It was not meant to be a secret. Of course, as soon as we were asked a relevant question by NAMA with respect to the success fee we responded within an hour.
I will focus on this. NAMA has said it did not know, and Mr. Neporent has agreed with its version today that Cerberus did not tell NAMA.
I think NAMA also agrees with our interpretation, at least as I have heard it in this committee, as to what was required to be disclosed and when.
The witness did not wait for my question.
I apologise.
NAMA says it was not aware that Brown Rudnick was Cerberus's legal advisers. It has said it repeatedly.
That is true. We did not disclose Brown Rudnick until, I think, 2 or 3 April 2014.
Cerberus told NAMA then that Brown Rudnick was its legal advisers.
Yes.
Was the witness not obliged to tell NAMA before that?
I do not believe so.

Has the Comptroller and Auditor General, I or somebody got it wrong when it is outlined in the report that prospective bidders for Project Eagle were required to seek "written consent from NAMA in relation to any advisors they wished to engage..."?

As we interpreted the non-disclosure agreement at the time, and my recollection is that NAMA has agreed with our interpretation in prior testimony before the committee, one is only required to disclose advisers that were to have access to receipt of information from the data room. We did not share information from the data room with Brown Rudnick.

It can be proved by showing they did not have access to the electronic data room. They would have had to log in, and they did not.

I welcome Mr. Neporent and I thank him for crossing the Atlantic to be a witness here. He is clarifying many issues we are trying to follow up on. This is an investigation and we are trying to get clarification on what is happening. In hindsight, is Mr. Neporent happy that the purchase price gave good value for money?
That remains to be seen, when the portfolio is worked out. I do not think we will lose money on the portfolio.

Mr. Neporent said 50% of the assets were Northern Ireland based. In the loan book, were the values in Northern Ireland higher than the values in Southern Ireland and the rest of the UK or wherever the other assets were?
Although my memory is not perfect, I believe approximately 80% of the value of the book was in Northern Ireland.

Was Mr. Neporent worried about it because of the political situation and the relationship with NAMA? Did he understand all that when he made the offer? Was he worried about rolling out these assets and how they would work out in the future?

That is part of the work we were doing to ensure we were comfortable investing in the North and that we would be able to work effectively with the borrowers and local stakeholders to work out these loans. Had we thought we were going to have a world war with every single borrower, we might not have bid. However, we got comfortable, and subsequent to our purchase it has been borne out. We have had a very good relationship in the region.
Did Mr. Neporent know about Brexit coming down the line? Was it spoken about? Was he worried about the consequences if the UK voted to leave the EU? Was it a consideration?
Brexit is a 2016 event and this was a 2014 event. I do not know that it was our radar at the time.
Was he aware of Brexit coming down the line?

Personally, I was not. I do not know if it was taken into consideration by other members of the investment committee. I do not think it was a high profile issue for our investment committee at the time.

Most NAMA representatives said the same. As has been said already, £15 million is a lot of money. Mr. Neporent said, in hindsight, if he had the choice again he might not give them that much money. In hindsight, if he were back again, and if he were paying by the hour, what value would he put on the information they gave him? I know it is hypothetical.

I cannot speculate, and I would prefer not to, on something like that. We made a commercial decision to enter into this engagement which we thought would help us get to where we wanted to be in the portfolio.

I understand. I am asking because £15 million is a lot of money and I wonder if it was value for money. Would it have been better to have paid by the hour, as was the case for other advisers, rather than paying the lump sum of £15 million?

That was not how the proposal was made. We were not given that option. We were told this was the arrangement they had with PIMCO and we could take it or not. They said if we took it they would have been pleased, and if we did not, they would offer it to another bidder. We did not have the opportunity or option to engage with them on another basis.

When Cerberus came in to bid, in February, was Mr. Neporent aware that PIMCO had originally offered £1.3 billion for the portfolio, that it had wanted to have a closed arrangement with NAMA, and that NAMA refused it and wanted to put it on the open market or on a closed market with named companies? Was he aware that the £1.3 billion was the original offer from PIMCO and was that his guideline or was it based on his own advisers that he offered £1.3 billion and then a reduced amount of £1.24 billion?
We had no sight of the prior process, therefore we had no idea that PIMCO had put a value on it. We were guided by the reserve price that was set for it and publicly disclosed by NAMA in the process.

Cerberus bought the loan book. We keep asking NAMA what would have happened had it rolled out an asset-by-asset sale over a longer period, and sold them individually or in small groups, rather than a loan book sale. Would Cerberus have been interested in buying the assets rolled out over time rather than buying the loan book in one go?

We would not have had an interest in an asset-by-asset sale. It would have been too much work. We prefer to do things on a concentrated basis. We would probably not have done it on an asset-by-asset basis. It would have required a tremendous infrastructure in Northern Ireland with a lot of servicing, back up, procedure, policy and IT. It is not worth it unless one gets a critical mass.
Cerberus had to have the critical mass, and became interested because there was critical mass.
Yes.

Cerberus has been working out the loans since 2014 and has already given information about how much it has sold off. Are things going well? Does Cerberus force sales or work out arrangements with the borrowers and try to work out the assets gradually? Is Cerberus putting pressure on borrowers? Does Cerberus work it through like a bank, or does it identify an asset it wants to get rid of and sell it off, end of story?

We wanted to make this clear and it is one of the reasons we were talking to the various stakeholders. Our experience across many portfolios in many jurisdictions is that it works out better in the end to have consensual resolutions be as large a percentage of the portfolio as possible. It is our business strategy. It was out business strategy and it has been our business strategy every other place we have done non-performing loan portfolio acquisition work, across Europe, the US and Asia. It is our preference.

I asked because I have heard through the grapevine that Cerberus is selling off some assets in Southern Ireland whose owners want to work them through, and that Cerberus is forcing their hands. That is speculation again.

I cannot comment on anything particular. All I can say is that our preferred method is to resolve things consensually. In a portfolio with approximately 2,200 loans, 900 properties and 55 connections, there will be some disagreements with borrowers. When we took over the portfolio, approximately 22% of it was already in enforcement of foreclosure proceedings started by NAMA. We have had to commence enforcement on a far lower percentage of the portfolio.
By when will Cerberus have all the properties in Project Eagle, which Cerberus purchased in 2014, sold off or worked through? Is there a timescale, or does Cerberus just keep going?

It is on an asset-by-asset basis. We are working with all the borrowers on business plans. Some may take an extended period of time. We came here as long-term players. We have invested much more money in Northern Ireland than in the Republic in other portfolios since Project Eagle. We have invested more than £20 billion in UPB in total, including Project Eagle. We have a long-term view of the process.
In hindsight, Mr. Neporent is glad he came to Ireland and got involved.
I think we are.

That is fair enough. Has Mr. Neporent any comment on the ongoing investigations which he identified, such as those of the National Crimes Agency, the US Securities and Exchange Commission, SEC, and US Department of Justice? Why does he think the investigations are happening and would Mr. Neporent like to elaborate on what he said?

I really cannot, given that they are ongoing investigations and I would like to be very mindful of not overstepping my bounds. There has been a great deal of public information about alleged irregularities and the authorities are investigating it, as they should.

Why is the USA investigation in particular taking place?

Can Mr. Neporent elaborate on, or explain, it?

All I can tell the Deputy is that we are co-operating with the Securities and Exchange Commission, SEC, and the Department of Justice in the United States. They have not told us who the subject of their investigations is so I could not shed any light on that.

Can Mr. Neporent tell me generally, so that we can understand the process because we are not in the business, the range of advisers Cerberus would employ on an issue like this, apart from legal and accounting?
Property valuation advisers, local brokers and servicing advisers to help us interact with the borrowers.
What does Mr. Neporent mean by servicing, for the lay person watching?

If I make a loan somebody has to pay attention to the collection of the interest and the payment of principal to make sure the papers are in order, payments are being made on a timely basis and notices are given. The Chairman can appreciate that in a portfolio of this size a large infrastructure is needed for that.
Would Cerberus employ insurance, planning or environmental advisers because it is taking on a lot of property? Did it do any of that?
Some of that is done pre-bid and some post-bid to understand the potential value of the underlying assets.

We are in the pre-bid situation. What happened afterwards is Cerberus’s affair. Did it employ any of those types of adviser? Other people have said they had insurance advisers and environmental consultants on board? Did Cerberus go that route?
There were 16 or 17 that we disclosed to NAMA in the process. I do not have each of them committed to memory but I would be happy to take a look and put each in a category.
Would Mr. Neporent send a note of that to the committee afterwards?
Sure.
How many of those advisers was Cerberus required to notify NAMA of? Mr. Neporent says there were 16 but only a couple of those would have had access to the data room.
I think everyone that we notified NAMA of had access to the data room. We notified it because we needed to give them access to the data room.
Were there any advisers hired by Cerberus who did not have access to the data room, who were notified to NAMA?
I do not believe so.
Brown Rudnick did not have access to the data room and Mr. Neporent is saying that is the principal reason Cerberus did not have to inform NAMA of it.
That is correct.

Everybody has asked about the service Brown Rudnick was offering to Cerberus, and the cost. How Cerberus spent its £15 million is its affair but there is one sentence I am intrigued by and Mr. Neporent has given a reason in paragraph 3.15 of his opening statement in which he states: “Brown Rudnick also told Cerberus that if Cerberus did not wish to enter into this arrangement, it would offer its services to another bidder.” Essentially Cerberus was closing it off going somewhere else. As a business person, I would have said, given that Cerberus was in a high bid situation part of the reason it might pay somebody who said it had an insider’s knowledge is to get the benefit and to close that person off going somewhere else. Let us be pragmatic about it.
The Chairman is absolutely right. That is something I had intended to say. That is exactly one of the reasons.
It might be one of the most valuable reasons because Cerberus did not want to have another bidder with an advantage that it did not have. That in itself was unquantifiable but a big issue.
That is precisely right.
Cerberus said it was not sure what it would get for the £15 million but it could not take the risk of him going to somebody else. That was a big factor.
I agree.
That has not been teased out so far. Does Mr. Neporent accept that was a factor?
I do.

Brown Rudnick made it clear that it had put approximately a year’s work into this going back to when it started with PIMCO. PIMCO told us in its letter to the committee, and Mr. Neporent need not be expected to know this, that in April 2013 it was approached by Mr. Keenan, a partner in Brown Rudnick. To be pragmatic, quite a bit of work had to be done by some people before they got to approach PIMCO. I would have assumed reading that letter that Brown Rudnick had been in the field with people, prior to the day it approached PIMCO because it must have gone to PIMCO with something. I would feel there is a strong possibility that the work on this had commenced quite a long time before March 2013 because it could not have started on that day. Mr. Neporent cannot comment on that because it was not working for Cerberus.

I can understand how there might have been an issue for Brown Rudnick not being able to disclose the information it got from the February-March period, the bidding period but there was no involvement with NAMA before the formal sales process commenced. I could see how any information Brown Rudnick had gathered through its own resources prior to the bid processing could not have been covered by a non-disclosure agreement with NAMA. Would Mr. Neporent think it would be free to use that type of information?

I specifically asked about that as part of the engagement. I did not know where it got the information and I wanted to ensure it was free to share it with us in an unlimited and unrestricted manner. It gave us such representation.

Mr. Neporent mentioned in paragraph 2.1 of his opening statement that Cerberus had an “unpaid principal balance, or UPB, of over $80 billion USD.” I presume the unpaid balance on Project Eagle was in the region of $5 billion.
I cannot do the math in my head but it was approximately £4.4 billion.

Yes, approximately $5 billion. Although this was Cerberus’s first involvement here it must have been one of its biggest transactions. It did 40 transactions at $80 billion, that is an average of $2 billion each and this one is coming in at approximately $5 billion. This would be quite a big transaction, not the biggest I am sure, or maybe it was.
It required a purchase price of £1.242 billion.
That is big by Cerberus’ standards.
That is big by anyone’s standards.

The fact that it was a cash only bid meant that Cerberus had to be in a position to write that cheque. How did that play out? Would Mr. Neporent have wished Cerberus could have syndicated or drawn other people in to make up the funding?
No. We typically like to do this ourselves, with our own process and servicing but a portfolio of this size is a very substantial commitment for anyone.
It was manageable by Cerberus.
Yes.
Mr. Neporent says Cerberus is one of the biggest loan management companies in the world.
Yes in terms of the acquisition of non-performing loans, NPLs, I think it has been reported by Cushman & Wakefield and others that we are one of the two or three largest in the world.

There was a time NAMA was the biggest loan book repository on the planet. Mr. Neporent says Cerberus has taken over from NAMA in that league.

Mr. Neporent has said he does not know who else was involved but did he feel Cerberus was in a competitive situation right to the end?
Absolutely.

Why did the meeting with the Minister for Finance and the former Secretary of State, Cerberus’s chairman, officials, the chairman and chief executive of NAMA, and senior officials in the Department of Finance happen the night before the bids were lodged? Has that been disclosed to us before?
No.
That particular meeting-----

The night before the bids closed. I am not sure. I do not remember too many witnesses telling us about that. Would it be unusual, for one of Cerberus's biggest bids, £1.3 billion, that the most senior people in the organisation would meet the most senior person in the organisation where it was lodging the bid the next day?
I do not think so. It was a very competitive process from our perspective in a condensed timeframe and we wanted to make sure there was nothing else we could do before we put the bid in.
Was NAMA happy to meet with Cerberus the day before the bids closed?
As far as I know. I was not at that meeting. I did not arrange it.

We will ask NAMA, not Cerberus, if it met Fortress, which we now know was the only other bidder in the field, within 24 hours of the bids closing. We will ask it about those two sets of meetings because I do not think that has been volunteered extensively to us.
That meeting was in the public domain.
Was the Comptroller and Auditor General aware of that?
It was in the public domain but we did not focus on it in particular.

The letter Mr. Neporent mentioned on 25 March is a bit like what was called the memorandum of understanding which issued months earlier from Cerberus to the Minister.

To which Minister was it addressed? Was it addressed to the Minister for Finance, Deputy Michael Noonan?
Yes, I believe it was addressed to the Minister for Finance, Deputy Michael Noonan.
Was it addressed to any Minister in Northern Ireland?
I do not believe so.
It was addressed to the Minister for Finance, Deputy Michael Noonan, only. I might have a few other questions, but I wanted to put those points to Mr. Neporent.
I thank Mr. Neporent for his continued co-operation. Did Cerberus have dealings with Brown Rudnick prior to Project Eagle?
Yes. Brown Rudnick was a service provider for us in the distressed debt trading field in the United States. I have a relationship with the head of the New York office, who is a contemporary of mine.
A contemporary.
I knew the firm very well for many years.

I suspected that might have been the case because just as Cerberus is a large player on the field, so too is Brown Rudnick; it is a considerable player. There was a history of dealing between Cerberus and Brown Rudnick.
Yes.
Who did Tuvi Keinan call when he cold-called Cerberus about offering its services?
He called one of my colleagues in our servicing business, Robert Falls.
Robert-----
Falls.
I thank Mr. Neporent.
Apparently, Mr. Falls and Mr. Keinan had worked together at one time in Morgan Stanley. They knew each other from those days.
They had worked together in Morgan Stanley.
Yes; that is my understanding.
Would it be fair to say that when they worked together in Morgan Stanley, they worked on the acquisition of a NAMA loan or loan portfolio?
I do not know that information.

If Mr. Neporent cared to suss it out and examine it, he would find it to be the case. I know it for certain in the case of Mr. Keinan because I have correspondence from Mr. Frank Daly which confirms that there was interaction between NAMA and Mr. Keinan when he worked for Morgan Stanley. Perhaps Mr. Neporent might recall this. It is a matter of public record.
I knew that Mr. Keinan had worked with NAMA. That is one of the things he discussed with us when he was trying to convince us to engage Brown Rudnick.
I wonder if Mr. Falls was involved in that transaction.
That I do not know.

It would be interesting to know. There was a personal relationship between Mr. Keinan and Mr. Falls. I am attributing nothing to Mr. Falls, whose name has not featured at all.

Looking at the time line and how all of this happened, on 12 March PIMCO withdrew because it had rumbled that a fee was payable to Mr. Cushnahan and was uncomfortable about it. In fact, it got in touch with NAMA to report all of this to it under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, with which I am sure Mr. Neporent is familiar.
I am.

Its compliance people became anxious and made contact with NAMA. NAMA has asserted that PIMCO was told to leave the process, but PIMCO is absolutely resolute that it left because it was unhappy that there had been a breach of compliance. It is resolute on the matter. Did Mr. Keinan or anyone else at any stage say to Mr. Neporent that PIMCO had left or that it was told to leave?
What was communicated to me in my conversation with Mr. Keinan was that PIMCO had withdrawn.
Mr. Neporent tells us that on 14 March contact was made with Cerberus.
Yes, between Mr. Keinan and Mr. Falls.
Then he passed it to Mr. Neporent. Is that correct?
There were some people in between, but it ultimately reached my desk.
On what date did it reach Mr. Neporent's desk?
I believe it was on or about 17, 18 or 19 March.
St. Patrick's Day. How appropriate that it was on St. Patrick's Day?
Did he receive a bowl of shamrock also?

According to Mr. Neporent, what transpired was that discussions were held in London. He stated, "Prior to engaging Brown Rudnick, the Cerberus legal and compliance team held discussions with Mr. Keinan and ... other partners at Brown Rudnick, including a partner based in London who had previously been ... head of enforcement."
Yes.
Is it at that stage that Mr. Neporent figured out and looked for the assurances on the non-disclosure agreement and what could and could not be shared?

That really was secondary in my mind. What was primary in my mind was that there was a government seller. Any time a government is involved one has to be concerned about the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the UK Bribery Act.
Yes; absolutely.

It was a large amount of money and I wanted to ensure the agreement was crystal clear that the money was going to a certain place only and, frankly, that I would not be sitting at something like this.
Yes.
That was my concern and it was one of the primary reasons we had Peter Bibby from Brown Rudnick involved.
Will Mr. Neporent repeat the gentleman's name?
Peter Bibby.
Bibby.
He was a Brown Rudnick partner and the former head of enforcement at the FSA in the United Kingdom.
At that stage, presumably, Brown Rudnick made it clear to Mr. Neporent that it had, in turn, availed of the services of Tughans in Belfast.
Yes.
Cerberus had no issue with it and assumed it to be okay.
Yes. It asked for our permission. I apologise. I have lost my train of thought. Will the Deputy, please, repeat the question?

I asked about Tughans. Cerberus was speaking to Brown Rudnick; the matter landed on Mr. Neporent's desk on or around St. Patrick's Day; he was looking for assurances and speaking to Brown Rudnick. He said Mr. Peter Bibby was involved.
Yes.
Obviously, Brown Rudnick was being upfront with Mr. Neporent in saying it was availing of the services and had the co-operation of Tughans and that it had been working on the portfolio.
Yes.
However, Mr. Neporent's testimony is that it never mentioned Mr. Frank Cushnahan.

No; it did mention him. As I mentioned in answer to one of the Deputy's prior questions, it mentioned that Mr. Frank Cushnahan had perhaps figured in the reason it had withdrawn because NAMA was unhappy that it was stated he would have a future role post-acquisition should PIMCO be the winning bidder.

Let me rephrase my question. Did Mr. Neporent ask Brown Rudnick about it or seek an assurance at that stage that Mr. Cushnahan would not be involved in the new scenario in Cerberus's dealings with Brown Rudnick?

I did not ask it in that specific way; I asked it in a more far-reaching and general way. I said I wanted to know that no one else was involved other than Brown Rudnick and Tughans. That covered everybody.
However, Mr. Neporent did not name-check Mr. Cushnahan.
I felt the way I did it, in a general way, covered everyone in the world, except Brown Rudnick and Tughans.

Although Mr. Cushnahan had been in the middle of the previous controversy. Cerberus then engaged their services on 24 March and we have established that it was bringing to the table information on debtors and assets. Interestingly, Mr. Neporent refers to an abstract of each loan, a view of the debt, business plans, etc. NAMA's testimony to the committee is that the debtors were being very awkward and not playing ball with it in producing these plans. However, Mr. Neporent states Brown Rudnick, Tughans and Mr. Cushnahan were able to produce some form of business plans for Cerberus' perusal.

Yes; some of them might have contained their view of what the business plans could be as opposed to being the actual borrower's business plans. I did not have direct sight of every piece of information in the diligence package.
I am sorry if this sounds like a simplistic question-----
That is okay.
-----but to whom was the information given that it had brought to the table? Who on Cerberus' side took possession of the abstracts, business plans and so on?
Several members of what we call a roll-up team, or deal-team, in London.
It is a roll-up team or deal team.
With these portfolios, we look at every single loan in the portfolio and ascribe a value to that loan. We will then roll it up to an aggregate value and a payment we could make.
That makes absolute sense to me. It is to them that the information would go.
Yes.
Is the witness saying they did not get the information until 24 March?
At least one and maybe two samples were shared as we were considering whether we were going to effect this engagement. Subsequent to the engagement, they produced whatever they had to.

Okay. That is fair enough. That demonstrates that Cerberus was not blindly taking a chance on the £15 million. It is entirely reasonable and sensible, and the company had to a have a sense that it was getting quality information. It established that by virtue of having sight of a number of samples, as the witness referred to them. It makes perfect sense to me. Not that I will ever have £15 million but if that was my money or much less, I assure the witness I would want to know I was getting bang for my buck.

Again, I did not say that. I said that what we had seen might have value but we did not have sight of the entire package before we entered into the agreement. We had not made the conclusion just based purely on the information that it was worth £15 million. We thought that having more information is better. As the Chairman mentioned and I should have mentioned in my prior remarks, keeping them off the field, or off the pitch as people say here, was part of our commercial decision.

On 24 March, they were officially engaged and on 25 March, Mr. Dan Quayle was in Stormont meeting Mr. Peter Robinson, former First Minister, Mr. Simon Hamilton, also of the Democratic Unionist Party and taken on as Minister for Finance and Personnel, and Mr. Ian Coulter of Tughans.

Yes, and that brings something to my attention. I think I misspoke earlier when I indicated the letter was given to the Minister for Finance, Deputy Noonan. It was given to First Minister Peter Robinson and his colleagues at that meeting on 25 March. I mixed those up. I apologise.
Okay. I was going to raise that with the witness.
That is the letter I mentioned.
The letter of intent.
It went to-----
It was the First Minister Peter Robinson. I misspoke. I apologise.
Did it go to the Minister for Finance, Deputy Noonan?
I do not know.
Grand. I noted the reference to the Minister, Deputy Noonan, earlier. Thank you.

Whatever misgivings the witness may have had around the quality of the debtor information being brought to the table, he could have been in no doubt as to their commitment to hook the company in with the relevant stakeholders. They were engaged on 24 March and, lo and behold, they were meeting the First Minister on 25 March, which is literally the day afterwards. They were as good as their word on that in terms of access to the DUP and Mr. Peter Robinson in particular.
Agreed.
We agree on that.
Yes.
At the meeting this letter was handed over to Mr. Peter Robinson. Is there a note somewhere or a minute of what transpired at that meeting?
I do not believe so, other than perhaps some e-mails from our colleagues saying what happened and that the meeting went well. There was nothing formal.
Is there anything we might have access to?
We could consider it.

If the witness could consider it, it would be most helpful. On 31 March, the meeting occurs as the Chairman has indicated. In this case it involves Mr. Frank Daly, and Mr. McDonagh was at the meeting. The Minister for Finance, Deputy Noonan, and senior officials from the Department were also party to the meeting. Who accompanied Mr. Snow to the meeting from Cerberus?

According to my notes the personnel were Secretary John W. Snow and Mr. Liam Strong, one of our staff based in London, as well as Mr. Billy Cooper, who is on Secretary Snow's staff, and Mr. Ron Bolger, one of our advisers in Ireland.
Who is that?

Mr. Bolger is an adviser we have retained in Ireland for a number of years. We retained him first two, three or four years ago in connection with our consideration of Allied Irish Banks and other assets.

Unlike in the North, Cerberus does not have anybody from Tughans or its partners at Brown Rudnick making an appearance at the Southern meeting. I am just making that as an observation. It is interesting, is it not?
I am not sure what the Deputy's point is. We were trying to meet all the stakeholders and it certainly was not our intention to exclude anyone.
Is it not a bit odd that the very persons being paid very generously and quite handsomely to facilitate the interaction with the stakeholders were not at the meeting? Who set up that meeting?
I do not know who set up that meeting.
Given that Mr. Ian Coulter was there, it seems Brown Rudnick and Tughans or whatever combination of those parties set up the Northern meeting. Did they set up the Southern meeting?
I do not know.
The company was paying them to get Cerberus plugged in with the stakeholders. Was that not the case?
To answer the question directly, I do not know who set up that meeting.
Will the witness find out?
I will try.

Could we find out? The bit that astonishes me, which has remained the position of Cerberus and NAMA, is that NAMA had no notion of Brown Rudnick being involved with Cerberus until 2 April. The witness may keep me right on those dates. In other words, the agency did not know Brown Rudnick had any involvement with Cerberus until the bid was in. To put it one way, I am a bit sceptical of that.
I need to allow Deputy Cullinane have his turn.

Will the witness find out who organised that meeting and if it was Brown Rudnick, Tughans or somebody acting on their behalf, given that it is what Cerberus was paying them for? It could be useful for the examination of this committee.

I thank the witness for being very patient. I have a number of quick points seeking clarification about times and dates. I will also seek clarification from the witness on a number of issues that he has raised but I am just not clear on some times and dates. In his opening remarks, Mr. Neporent indicated that at no time prior or subsequent to involvement in Project Eagle has Cerberus worked directly or indirectly with PIMCO in respect of the Project Eagle process. I would have thought that was obvious and I am wondering why it was put in the opening remarks.
I have listened to many of the hours of testimony in this committee and I heard the allegation made on a number of occasions and I thought it was something I wanted to put to bed.
I am not sure that allegation would have been made. What is true is that two companies, Brown Rudnick and Tughans, which did work with PIMCO eventually worked with Cerberus as well. That was raised.
To help the Deputy, Mr. McEnery of the audit committee stated that he asked at the board meeting whether PIMCO was a Trojan horse for Cerberus.
He is the single only person to have raised it.
That is how it was raised.
I was wondering why but that is helpful.
It got my attention.
He indicated that before any approach from Brown Rudnick, two law firms were working with Cerberus. It was Goodbody and-----
Linklater.
Yes. When did Cerberus employ its services and was it specific to Project Eagle?
We use both those law firms quite a bit and for many things.
Yes, but they were employed to do specific work relating to Project Eagle.
Yes.
When?
I do not know. I would assume virtually immediately after we were contacted and we decided we wanted to participate in the process.

Will the witness provide us with those dates by correspondence? There are some other dates as well.

On what date was Cerberus first approached by Brown Rudnick? When was there a formal arrangement in place between the two?
The first approach was made on 14 March. The engagement letter was signed either on the night of 23 March or on 24 March.

There seem to be clear lines of demarcation between providing legal services and providing a range of other services. Would I be right in saying that the other two firms that were previously employed were doing a lot of legal work, contractual work, maybe all sorts of other work, but that Brown Rudnick was doing a different type of job or providing a different type of service? Would that be fair?
They were providing legal services and strategic services. We were not engaging Linklaters-----
Can Mr. Neporent differentiate between legal and strategic services?

Sure. Some of the legal services Brown Rudnick was providing included advice on the construct of our bid. The strategic services consisted of advice on how to place our bid. Section 5 of the NAMA proposal requires a statement of strategic intent as part of the bid, so that is the strategic part with which Brown Rudnick was helping us.
This was obviously worked out, but Mr. Neporent got an initial cold call approach by Brown Rudnick-----
Yes.
-----to say it could provide a service.
Yes.

It obviously would have set out the nature of that service, and we went through that earlier. Mr. Neporent was asked at that point whether Brown Rudnick had made him aware that it had previously worked with PIMCO, and he said it had done so.
Yes.

However, when Mr. Neporent asked why Brown Rudnick was no longer working for PIMCO, I think Mr. Keenan's response was that he did not really know, but then he did when he volunteered, in terms of Mr. Cushnahan, that any difficulty was post-contractual. Is that correct?
Yes. NAMA was concerned that Mr. Cushnahan would be involved in a post-award scenario.
We now know that is not correct.
I am aware of that. I do not know that we know that but I am aware of the allegations.

They are more than allegations at this point. It is possible, then, that Mr. Neporent was not given the full information, or it seems he was not given the full information, at that point on Brown Rudnick's relationship with both Tughans and Mr. Cushnahan.
That is possible.

This raises a very important point because what is more important is the conversations Mr. Neporent would have had with NAMA and any perceived conflicts of interest. I am reading through Mr. Neporent's opening statement. Paragraph 4.3 outlines the general obligations Cerberus placed on Brown Rudnick to provide "certifications, representations and warranties covering a number of issues, including compliance with anti-bribery and corruption laws". Are these just general compliance issues?
Yes, although in this case it was more than customary in a legal engagement letter because of the Government's participation as a seller.

Paragraph 4.5 states that NAMA also requested certain assurances from Cerberus "that no fee, commission or other remuneration or payment was payable to any current or former Board member of NAMA, any current or former member of the Executive of NAMA, or any current or former member of an advisory committee of NAMA". Was that the first time Mr. Neporent was contacted by NAMA about any conflicts of interest? On what date was there discussion between NAMA and Cerberus about a contract or potential arrangement with Brown Rudnick?
I think it happened relatively promptly after we disclosed Brown Rudnick in response to its question about success fees.
Does Mr. Neporent know the date of that discussion?
I guess it was around 3 April 2014.

I wish to bring up the Comptroller and Auditor General's report, specifically finding No. 57. Before I do so, did NAMA ask Mr. Neporent at all about the precise nature of his engagement with Brown Rudnick? Did it even ask him when he first engaged Brown Rudnick and the nature of those services? Was that part of the conversation?
No. NAMA never made any inquiries in that regard.

One of the criticisms of the Comptroller and Auditor General reads, "NAMA only learned of Brown Rudnick's engagement with Cerberus on 2 April 2014, and do not appear to have asked Cerberus when it engaged Brown Rudnick, or what the precise nature of the services Brown Rudnick and Tughans were providing [to Cerberus]." Is that correct?
That is true.
NAMA never asked for that information.
That is correct.

NAMA therefore never informed Mr. Neporent that there was any difficulty with Mr. Cushnahan or that there was any previous history. We had very lengthy discussions with representatives from NAMA in this committee at which they were shocked by, and very obviously exercised about, the fact that there was an arrangement between Mr. Cushnahan, Tughans, Brown Rudnick and PIMCO, so shocked that PIMCO had to go, and they were going to force PIMCO out of the process. It was a clear conflict of interest to them that was very concerning. They then have a conversation with Cerberus about a success fee that involves Brown Rudnick and Tughans and they do not mention Mr. Cushnahan or any difficulties or issues.
That is correct.
Has NAMA never raised this?
It did not raise it with us before it awarded the bid and it did not raise it in the extended period between the awarding of the bid and the closing.
When NAMA sought assurances, they were general assurances, but there was never any mention of Mr. Cushnahan.
That is correct.
That is fine.
Are we finished or did Deputy Connolly want to come in? Is Deputy Aylward finished his questioning?
Deputy Connolly asked me earlier about the non-disclosure agreement.
Yes.
I am not sure if she has copies of non-disclosure agreements.
I do not. I asked for them when the committee last met.
It is possibly-----
Mr. McCarthy might clarify that.

-----a bit more complex than access to the data room. There is also a proviso in the non-disclosure agreement that those who have signed it may not disclose any of what are called the information materials to an external adviser unless such external adviser has been notified to NAMA and prior written consent has been accepted.
Brown Rudnick and Tughans did not access the data room for Cerberus.

That is right, but no person who has signed a non-disclosure agreement can disclose any of the information materials he or she has acquired. There is a definition in the non-disclosure agreement of the scope of the information materials which may not be disclosed to an external adviser without notifying NAMA in advance.
For clarification, did PIMCO get access to the data room?
Yes.
PIMCO was therefore in the data room prior to-----
Yes.
We are not talking about Cerberus. We are talking about PIMCO. PIMCO had access to the data room.
It had access to it.
That is important. It had full access to it.
It did, and the question is-----
That is a very important point.
Yes, but the question is that it gave an assurance that it had no contractual-----
Yes, it would have lost access-----
I presume representatives of PIMCO would have taken notes. When-----
We cannot assume anything.
For the 12-month period that it was there, from April until-----

Take the 12 months in the lead-up to the bidding process commencing before the access to the data room. PIMCO had access to information the previous autumn, but this non-disclosure agreement, when Brown Rudnick was working for PIMCO outside of the data room during that sales process, the non-disclosure agreement did not-----
Any material it might have had prior to signing a non-disclosure agreement it would have been at liberty to provide.

Exactly. Therefore, the information it had assembled over the previous 12 months would have been free to pass on to another party, in this case Cerberus, if it chose to do so, but not information assembled while Brown Rudnick was working for PIMCO after it signed the non-disclosure agreement.
However, neither Cerberus nor any of its other advisers would have been at liberty to disclose any of the information materials to Brown Rudnick.
Wow.
That is an aspect of it as well.

Did Mr. Neporent follow that last point? There were a series of advisers, and the Comptroller and Auditor General says that any information Mr. Neporent's people had received in the data room or through a non-disclosure agreement, they were not free to disclose it to Brown Rudnick or-----
Yes, I understand the point.
Is Mr. Neporent satisfied that did not happen?

Subsequent to the transaction and in connection with preparing for this hearing, there may have been some information that our people discussed with Brown Rudnick that may have resulted in a technical violation of the NDA, including things like the change in the reserve price that was communicated.
Will Mr. Neporent go back through that again because this is news? Will he repeat the point? In preparation for what meeting? Who might have done what?

For today. As I was reviewing these materials, it is possible that some of our people working on this may have made statements to Brown Rudnick with respect to information as defined in the NDA. That would have been a technical violation of the NDA.
Prior to the lodging of the bid on 1 April.
Yes.
Wow.
Yes, I think that is possible.
Who did Mr. Neporent notify of this technical breach before saying it here?
No one. That would be an issue as between us and NAMA that just came to my attention relatively recently and as far as I can tell, that would have had no effect on the bid whatsoever.
NAMA would be entitled to have an opinion on whether it did or did not have an effect on that.
That would be between us and NAMA, sure, yes.

As soon as it came to Mr. Neporent's attention that there might have been a technical breach in terms of passing information to Brown Rudnick and Tughans prior to the bid being lodged, why did he not notify NAMA?
We will consider doing that. Frankly, it did not seem like a very big deal because the nature of the information was relatively insignificant.
Are there any other complications in terms of the bid process, from Mr. Neporent's point of view, in any of the ongoing investigations outside of our examination here?
Not that I am aware of.

The chairman and the chief executive of NAMA will be in here next week. It would be helpful if Mr. Neporent had that conversation with them before then so that we can take it up with NAMA, subject to commercial confidentiality, etc., in public session.
We will consider that.

It would be helpful because there would be an open question to NAMA unless Cerberus and NAMA talk in the meantime. By next week, we would like to have information on this topic. Mr. Neporent has said he will consider that.
We will.
I call Deputy McDonald. At this stage, we are on the final furlong.
We are on the final lap.
I said the final furlong.

I have two issues. First, are there any other matters that came to Mr. Neporent's attention in preparation for this meeting that he has not placed on the record? I would have expected Mr. Neportent, if he does not mind me saying, to have stated it in his opening statement merely to give us the benefit of the information that there had been a technical violation of the non-disclosure agreement rather than leaving it to chance. Obviously, it came to Mr. Neporent's attention and it would be material to our considerations. Are there any other matters that came to Mr. Neportent's attention as he prepared for this session that he now wishes to place on the record?
I do not believe so, no.
Second, could Mr. Neporent give us a sense of his interactions and relationship with Lazard in the course of this transaction?

It was the NAMA adviser. Lazard knows us. It knows our business and during the bid process, we had lots of conversations with Lazard about the process, information flow and what NAMA expected to see from us.
Was Mr. Neporent's interaction with Lazard different in this transaction than in previous transactions?
No, I do not think so.
Was it more truncated, more intense?

It was truncated because the time was truncated and we had less time to discuss things with each other, but in terms of the sum and substance of the conversations, there was nothing unusual about it at all.

Did Mr. Neporent know that Lazard had a different kind of role in respect of dealing with this portfolio as against other property or loan sales advisers? Did he have no sense that this was very much a bespoke situation?
I am not sure-----
I am just asking whether Mr. Neporent had a sense of that, no?

I am not sure what that relates to. It was not my adviser. It was NAMA's adviser and it is for NAMA to choose the terms and conditions of its engagement of NAMA and the terms and conditions of the bid process.
I accept that. Did Mr. Neporent have a conversation with anyone from Lazard at any stage in respect of PIMCO and its withdrawal?
No.
Did Lazard never bring that to Mr. Neporent's attention or make a commentary on it?
Someone may have mentioned it but it is not something I focused on.
Are we concluded?

There is one small point that I think needs to be put on the record. Mr. Neporent stated earlier that the first time NAMA would have approached Cerberus and asked about issues around Brown Rudnick was on 2 April, but would it be right to say the deal where Cerberus was announced as the bidder was concluded on 4 April, two days later?
There was a press release on 4 April.
There was only two days to inquire about these issues. It seems a very short timeframe.
There was less than two days.
Less than two days even.
It was very tight.
I am not sure what the Deputy's point is. Is there a question?

No, I merely wanted to put on the record that there was a discussion between Mr. Neporent's company and NAMA in respect of Cerberus's engagement with Brown Rudnick. Brown Rudnick obviously was a difficulty for it because of its relationship with PIMCO and Mr. Cushnahan. Mr. Neporent stated that it never mentioned Frank Cushnahan to him when he had a conversation with it. My point is that the first it heard of any association between Mr. Neporent's company and Brown Rudnick was on 2 April, and yet the deal was closed on 4 April. It is more a question for NAMA, as to why it did not conduct more due diligence in regard to all this.

We will address that to NAMA. It was clear, when Mr. Daly was here a month ago, that it happened very late, it was very tight and very quick and that there were e-mails flying all around the place to get those undertakings at short notice. Mr. Daly said that and we can take that up with him on Thursday next.

I seek a simple "yes" or "no" answer. I merely want to be fair to a witness who was here yesterday. I think Mr. Neporent clarified it already. In his written submission in September 2015 to the Northern Ireland Assembly, Mr. Neporent mentioned meeting the deputy First Minister, Mr. Martin McGuinness. Mr. Neporent clarified today that he did not actually meet him. It is just that I put it to the deputy First Minister yesterday. In paragraph 2.8, Mr. Neporent stated he met a number of Northern Ireland politicians, and he mentioned the former First Minister, Mr. Peter Robinson, and Mr. McGuinness, among others. Mr. Neporent stated he actually met him.
I am sorry, what is the Deputy referring to? Which document?
The Northern Ireland Assembly committee in Belfast.
It was a written submission by Cerberus.
Mr. Neporent made it clear it was September.
To the DFP, yes.
It was afterwards, but not before. Mr. Neporent did not meet him before. That is wrong, in a sense, or Mr. Neporent clarified that it was in September 2014 he met him, not prior to the sale.
That is correct. Our first face-to-face, I believe, was in September.

I will conclude the meeting. I thank Mr. Neporent for being with us here today. He has been very helpful. I wish him every success in his business activities and thank him for taking time out to be with us here today and for travelling to Dublin. I also thank the Comptroller and Auditor General and his staff for being here today.

We will adjourn until 10 a.m. on Tuesday, 22 November 2016, when we will meet representatives of Lazard, the sales agent contracted by NAMA.
We asked for a copy of the standards.
We will get them.
Have they been asked?
I will double-check it.
The witness withdrew.
The committee adjourned at 4.38 p.m. until 10 a.m. on Thursday, 22 November 2016.
Joint Oireachtas Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Defence

The Joint Committee met at 10:00

MEMBERS PRESENT:

Deputy Seán Barrett, Senator Ivana Bacik, Deputy Seán Crowe, Senator Gabrielle McFadden. Deputy Tony McLoughlin, Deputy Maureen O'Sullivan,

In attendance: Deputy Bobby Aylward.

DEPUTY BRENDAN SMITH IN THE CHAIR.
The joint committee met in private session until 10.20 a.m.
Situation in Syria and Ukraine: Discussion

I welcome the Russian Federation's ambassador to Ireland, H.E. Mr. Maxim Peshkov, to today's meeting to discuss, among other items, the situation in Syria and Ukraine. We are all shocked on a daily basis by the suffering of the people of Syria, particularly the people in Aleppo where the constant bombardment has affected so many lives killing and injuring thousands of civilians. The rest of the world has a duty to do everything in its power to ensure this ceases as soon as possible. As we in this country are very aware, this can only be achieved by dialogue between the opposing groups. The carnage and horrors inflicted upon the people of Syria cannot be allowed to continue.

Before I call on the ambassador to make his contribution, I remind members, witnesses and those in the Visitors Gallery to ensure their mobile phones are switched off completely for the duration of the meeting as they cause interference with the recording and broadcasting equipment in the chamber even in silent mode. I remind members of the long-standing parliamentary practice to the effect that they should not comment on, criticise or make charges against a person outside the House or an official either by name or in such a way as to make him or her identifiable. I draw the attention of witnesses to the fact that by virtue of section 17(2)(l) of the Defamation Act 2009, witnesses are protected by absolute privilege in respect of their evidence to the committee. However, if they are directed by the committee to cease giving evidence on a particular matter and they continue to so do, they are entitled thereafter only to a qualified privilege in respect of their evidence. They are directed that only evidence connected with the subject matter of these proceedings is to be given and they are asked to respect the parliamentary practice to the effect that, where possible, they should not criticise or make charges against any person, persons or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable.

I now call on H.E. Mr. Maxim Peshkov to make his opening remarks.

I am very grateful for this invitation. The direct exchange of views on any issues of interest to both sides is positive and helpful to deepening the understanding between us, our countries and our countries' politicians.

First of all, it is my duty to say a couple of words about the bilateral relations between Russia and Ireland. I must stress that we are ready for business interaction on all levels, including contacts between parliamentarians of both countries. In previous years, Russian and Irish parliamentarians planned some positive initiatives, for example, the boosting of activities of the group of friends of Russia in the Dáil and the visit of the speaker of the council of federation, the upper house, of the federal assembly of the Russian Federation, Mrs. Valentina Matvienko, to Ireland.

Unfortunately, I do not have the exact figures for this year, but in 2015, the volume of Russian-Irish bilateral trade decreased by 32.5% in comparison with 2014 and came to $1.1 billion. Russian exports fell by 19% and came to $271.6 million. Imports from Ireland dropped by 36% to $831.6 million. Therefore, Ireland is on the slightly more positive side from the point of view of our trade exchange. This year, we have very interesting projects of co-operation between Russia and Ireland, mainly in aviation. I am sure that these plans and projects will grow wider and deeper.

Ireland ranks in seventh place among foreign investors to Russia, behind Germany, the UK, China, the Netherlands, Luxemburg and Cyprus. As we see it, our task is to preserve gained potential of the trade and economic relations and, if possible, to increase it by introducing new projects in spheres of mutual beneficial interest. I must stress that economics and trade are not the only focus of our attention. We have very close relations and co-operation in fields of humanitarian activity, education, arts, culture and so on and so forth. The committee will know that annually in Russia we have traditional Irish events, such as St. Patrick's Day. We also celebrate a pancake day in Russia, as is done in Ireland. It is one of our biggest cultural events. Groups and artists from Russia come to Ireland from time to time to show their art. As far as I know, at the end of this month, there will be a ballet group from St. Petersburg and an opera group from Russia performing in Ireland. That is ongoing.

I prefer not to lecture. I prefer to answer questions.

There were two points on the proposal for our meeting - Syria and Ukraine. The main point of our position on Syria is that the only possible way to solve the Syrian crisis is through political means. As far as we understand, the results of the last contact between our President and President-elect Trump was that this point is mutual for both sides. We will see how we will manage it but the only forces that must be and are excluded from the peace process are terrorists, mainly ISIS and Jabhat al-Nusra. Those two forces are officially proclaimed as terrorist organisations. They are the main goals of our attacks in Syria and, as far as we know, they are the main goals of the attacks by the coalition led by the United States in Iraq.

As for Aleppo, unfortunately, too many fakes and lies are circulating about this part of Syria including the bombing of civilians, the use of unconventional weapons and so on. The Chairman is right. Civilians are being killed there but the question is by whom. As far as we know, there are dozens of shelling incidents every day from the eastern part of Aleppo against the western part of Aleppo. Members will know that this eastern part of Aleppo is under the control of terrorists mixed with opposition forces. The western part is under the control of the Government of Syria.

Accusations and allegations have been made, particularly in recent days, that Russia is using its air force to bomb and so on. I stress and remind the members that as of today, it has been exactly one month since we used our air force in Aleppo. We stopped it on 17 October, one month ago from today. Syria's air force is doing the same, therefore, allegations or accusations about Russia bombing schools, hospitals and so on in Aleppo are a complete lie. There was a briefing in the State Department yesterday at which the official representative, if I am not mistaken, spoke about six hospitals and one school that was bombed and so on. He was asked to show the address of the school and the hospitals. There was no answer. Every time we ask for the facts in terms of where, who and how, we do not get an answer.

With an array of American and Russian military satellites over this zone, which can control every square metre of the situation, it is very questionable as to why they do not show maps or video materials. Where is the evidence? If real evidence is shown, it is okay. If not, it is a lie. I am sure there will be more questions about Syria.

As for Ukraine, I will be very short. Our position is the Minsk agreements must be fulfilled. It is the only way out of this situation in the eastern parts of Ukraine.

Before I call on Deputy Maureen O'Sullivan, how does the ambassador see Russia's role in ensuring humanitarian access and protection of civilians in the Syrian conflict? With current reports of assaults on Homs and Idlib, as well as Aleppo, does the ambassador believe that the Russia and Syrian Governments are doing everything required to protect civilians as required under international law?

Not only do I believe but I am sure that we are doing everything we can. It is impossible to guarantee 100% the security of every civilian. Does the Chairman know that for more than one month we organised and guaranteed six humanitarian routes to eastern Aleppo, as well as two additional routes for the opposition, as we can call it, to leave eastern Aleppo? Unfortunately, very few people use these routes. Why? The radicals on that side of Aleppo closed these routes, meaning very few people have had a chance to go away from Aleppo.

In the Syrian Government part of Aleppo, there are camps and hospitals for people coming from eastern Aleppo. Just yesterday, we sent six children from Aleppo to Russia for treatment. They have special diseases which could not be treated in Syria itself. The six children, with their parents, are now in Russia going through this period of treatment. These are not wounds from shooting, but serious diseases like musculoskeletal diseases. Every week, we are sending our own humanitarian assistance to Aleppo.
